awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: Home+, An Intelligent and Interoperable Suite of Robotic Furnishings, Learning and Evolving with Their Users
awd_abstract_narration:
The number of older persons in the United States is substantially increasing, as is the cost of health care. Accompanying these trends is a growing scarcity of caretakers, care deliverers, and care facilities to attend to our growing elder population. Technology supporting health for older adults tends to be limited to computerized monitoring systems and, potentially someday in the future, as assistive 'humanoid' robots that look and function something like us. Our homes and their many furnishings, meanwhile, remain conventional, low-tech, and maladaptive to life changes. To promote independent living, this research team from architectural design, robotics, and human factors explores how our homes can be outfitted with furnishings of advanced functionality. This project, home+, is a collection of robotic home furnishings that fits easily into any conventional home to increase the quality of life of individuals with impaired mobility and cognitive functioning by enabling routine domestic activities. This research project will: (1) establish the needs and wants of older people wishing to age in place, identifying those aspects of the home+ concept that best promise to support independent living; (2) design robotic furnishings, accordingly; (3) test these furnishing to determine how well they interact with each other and with the people that use them; (4) define the choreography by which these furnishings and their users interact; and (5) evaluate how well home+ supports typical users performing ten routine home tasks that define a capacity for independent living. The team will gain insights not only from the targeted populations and healthcare professions who may benefit most by home+, but also from a wider audience. This outreach aspect of the home+ project will culminate in a workshop that seeks marketplace and practice support for advancing the prototype. 

The majority of seniors want to age in place in their homes. To realize this goal, this project will: (1) conduct a needs assessment of older adults; (2) iteratively co-design and usability test robotic furnishings that recognize, communicate with, and partly remember each other in interaction with human users (interoperability); (3) define the pattern language of interactions for this cyber-human system; and (4) evaluate the efficacy of home+ by comparing performance on 10 routine home tasks defining a capacity for independent living for individuals with and without home+. Drawing on research and formalism in distributed robotics, the team will focus efforts on implementing and evaluating three software environments for home+: (1) a centralized architecture, with all sensory information, processing, command and control at a single source; (2) a distributed architecture, with localized sensing, processing, and control, and minimal interactions between elements; and (3), a combination of the first two, with a dedicated interface layer between the high-level strategies of (1) and the reactive behaviors of (2). Intellectually, this approach can be viewed as establishing a bridge between traditional robotics and smart, robotically enhanced, physical built environments.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report, October 1, 2020, to September 30, 2021, a no-cost extension year.

For this project, my team strove to answer two fundamental questions:

How can homes be outfitted with intelligent hardware enabling independent living?

If such a thing is constructed, is it both usable by seniors and useful for aging in place?

Our response focused on a pair of robotic furnishings - a floor lamp and a side table - that we call home+ integrated into existing home environments. The two furnishings offer the usual affordances we expect from a floor lamp and side table, but they also are mobile robots that have grippers to manipulate aspects of the house interior (e.g., open a drawer or cabinet door; shine a light where needed) and both pick things up (from the floors, shelves and worksurfaces of our homes) and move things between themselves, their users, and across the home.

The key deliverables were the pair of human-centered, iteratively designed prototypes of the pair of robotic furnishings - table and lamp - and results from a series of interaction studies with these prototypes that invited stakeholders (both older adults and their healthcare providers) to offer their input and assessment. We learned from older adults and their healthcare providers that the home+ pair of robots was a welcomed addition to the households of older adults, and that the robots show promise to enable older adults to perform activities of daily living as defined by the CS-PFP 10 metric adopted by medical staff to assess the independence of their older patients. We also studied finer-grain aspects of the robots' behavior, such as stakeholder preferences for how fast and accordingly to which paths the robots moved in the home, which interfaces stakeholders prefer using to control the robots, and how autonomous stakeholders believe these robots should be. Results of the studies, at appropriate developmental stages, informed next iterations of the prototypes. Altogether, the research team developed five iterations of the working, full-scale prototypes, with the final prototype currently being completed for final, summative usability and efficacy evaluation in the PI's new home lab at Cornell.

The key broader impact of the research is home+ itself, a pair of robotic furnishings that fit well within everyday human habitation. Our broader aim with the home+ project is to empower inhabitants to remain independent for as long as possible, even as their physical capabilities change over time. In addition to the expected broader impacts of publishing and mentoring, PI Green offered public school talks and hosted school groups, mentored PhD and postdoc CISE students of color - the very next generation - and met with high school students around the world in a research summit of future engineers.

SPECIFIC OUTCOMES FOR THIS REPORTING PERIOD

As per Cornell University COVID policy, our research team only had full access to its Cornell research lab from July 1. PI Green is pleased to report that two students in mechanical engineering joined the home+ team at the start of the current Fall semester to complete the fifth and final prototype and to conduct a summative experiment with these prototypes engaging older adults.

During the pandemic, evaluating our prototypes in person with elder human participants was precluded. The research team pivoted to online user studies, conducting real-time, virtual interaction studies and surveys with both medical clinicians of various specialties (who routinely attend to older adults, our target population) and with individuals drawn from the targeted population itself. A summary of results is presented above in the SUMMARY. The outcomes of the study with clinicians are reported in a paper to be presented at CHASE 21 (the IEEE/ACM Conference on Connected Health Applications, Systems, and Engineering Technologies) and published in the Elsevier journal, Smart Health.

In the online study that followed the one with the clinicians, we engaged members of the targeted population: ten older individuals who currently use or have used a walker and live independently at home. When comparing study results from the older adult, walker-users to the healthcare providers, the most frequent method of interaction for everyone was voice commands. All participants saw the benefit of having a bin on wheels that can attach to one or both robots, used carrying things since they can't use their hands to carry objects. The participants understood how these robotic furnishings work on a basic level, how the furnishings might help them, and how the furnishings can help with daily tasks.

The lessons from these two online studies informed the design of our final, higher-fidelity prototypes. Our hope for the home+ lamp and table robots are captured in the words of a participant, a former healthcare provider at an assisted living and skilled nursing facility: I can see that this could be such a great blessing to many I have cared for.
